utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Is anyone else troubled by the Spider-Man theme song?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Why would it trouble you? It’s, like, your third favourite cartoon theme song.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It is, right behind do-do-do-do-do Inspector Gadget., and Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, heroes in a half-shell.

utterance.speaker: Howard and Raj (together)
utterance.content: Turtle power!

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: However, the Spider-Man lyrics posit that Spider-Man, Spider-Man does whatever a spider can.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yeah, so?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I can think of many things Spider-Man can’t do that a spider can. One, crawl in your ear and die. Two, legally leave Guatemala without a passport. Three, have sex with a spider.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: an we change the subject? Spiders give me the jeebie-jeebies.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: It’s heebie-jeebies.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I know, but that sounds anti-Semitic. Anyway, I was thinking we could have a little film festival tonight. The theme, movies that killed their franchises.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh. Like Jaws 4, Indiana Jones 4, Daredevil 1.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Miss Congeniality 2: Armed and Fabulous. I mean, you know a movie’s bad when my homegirl Sandy B can’t save it.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Penny’s working tonight, I’m in.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Not me. I’m having dinner with Bernadette and her parents.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Fun. We know how much you love that.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: It’s torture. Especially with her dad. We have nothing in common.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You know what I like to do when I’m forced to speak with those beneath my intellectual station? I bring up an interesting topic, like the difference between Spider-Man and spiders.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Thanks, Sheldon. I’ll try that with my father-in-law.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, you can’t use that one. That’s mine. Uh, try this one for an ice-breaker. Uh, despite popular lore, there is no place in the continental United States, Alaska or Hawaii from which one can dig straight through the centre of the earth and come up in China.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Great, thank you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Actually, you can’t have that one either. It’s too good. Sorry.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: What about you, Sheldon? Do you have any plans tonight?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Sadly, yes. Amy’s taking me to a memorial service. It’s for one of her colleagues who is of Asian descent, so my planned conversational gambit is to casually remark that no matter how deep they dig his grave, he’ll never make his way back to China.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: That should lighten the mood.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: What can I say? I put the fun in funeral.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Amy. Amy. Oh, right, funeral. Amy.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Hello, Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m not allowed to wear my Silver Surfer neck tie, but you can wear a bathrobe?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I think I’m too sick to go to the funeral.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You’re sick? You poor kid. Well, see ya.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Sheldon, aren’t you gonna take care of me?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Me? No. No, I’m not that kind of doctor.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: But our relationship agreement clearly states that when one of us is sick, the other must take care of them.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, no, I see the confusion. No, the intent behind that clause was to force you to take care of me when I’m ill. When you’re feeling better, you’ll think that’s funny.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Never mind. Good night, Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Amy. Amy. Amy. I made a commitment in writing to comfort you in times like this. Additionally, you are my girlfriend, and I care about your well-being.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Thank you, Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You’re welcome. Now let’s get this over with.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: So, how have you been?

utterance.speaker: Mr. Rostenkowski
utterance.content: Fine.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Good. Fine is good. How you liking retirement?

utterance.speaker: Mr. Rostenkowski
utterance.content: It’s fine.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I’m sensing a theme. You ever really think about the Spider-Man theme song? How’s that dinner coming?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: I just put it in. It’s gonna be a while.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I like rare chicken. Let’s do this.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: You could die.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Death by chicken. That’s a pretty fowl way to go.

utterance.speaker: Mrs. Rostenkowski
utterance.content: Here’s another beer, honey.

utterance.speaker: Mr. Rostenkowski
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: So, Mrs. Rostenkowski, you took that trip to the Grand Canyon. How was it?

utterance.speaker: Mrs. Rostenkowski
utterance.content: It was good.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Had no idea you were the chatty one.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: 102.2. Exactly what it was half an hour ago. It’s like you’re not even trying to get better.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Sheldon, you don’t get over the flu in half an hour.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, not with that attitude.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I have to say, I’m finding your bedside manner a little lacking.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m sorry. I just want you to get better as soon as possible. And with that goal in mind, let me ask you a question. Do you believe in the placebo effect?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Of course I do. There have been many studies proving its validity.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Great. Now, this may look like a Tic Tac, but it is really a powerful medication specifically designed to cure your illness as well as freshen your breath.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Sheldon, this isn’t helping. Why don’t you just let me get some rest.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: How can you sleep? I’m not done making you feel better. I still have to put a cold rag on your head, sing to you and apply VapoRub to your chest.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: You, you want to rub something on my chest?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yes. All over it.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Maybe we should start with that.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Now you’re being a responsible patient. Now, you may notice some tingling.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Oh, I’m counting on it.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay, dig in.

utterance.speaker: Mr. Rostenkowski
utterance.content: Hold up. Bless us, O Lord for these Thy gifts which we are about to receive from Thy bounty through Christ our Lord. Amen.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Took the words right out of my mouth.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: So, Dad, have you done any fishing lately?

utterance.speaker: Mr. Rostenkowski
utterance.content: I’m going next weekend.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh, you like to fish?

utterance.speaker: Mr. Rostenkowski
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Sure. I can hear it in your voice.

utterance.speaker: Mrs. Rostenkowski
utterance.content: Oh, if he didn’t like it, he wouldn’t go.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: You know, I hadn’t thought of that. Help me.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Hey, Dad, maybe you could take Howard fishing sometime. Give you guys a chance to get to know each other better.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: No, no. We know each other well enough. He’s been talking my ear off all night.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Howie, I think you’d have fun.

utterance.speaker: Mr. Rostenkowski
utterance.content: Fine, you can tag along.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Terrific. My two favorite fellas gone fishin’.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Well, hang on a second, Bernie. Next weekend, we have that thing.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: What thing?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: You know, the thing.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Oh, that thing. No, I cancelled that thing.

utterance.speaker: Mr. Rostenkowski
utterance.content: All right, it’s settled. You and I are going fishing.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Great. Thanks for the help.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I’ve never even been fishing. This is gonna be a disaster.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: If you don’t want to look foolish doing something, you should practice. Do you know how many Beef Wellingtons I made by myself before I invited you guys over? I’ll give you a hint. You can see them here, here and here.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Raj is probably right. You should get someone to give you some pointers.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Do either of you guys know how to fish?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: No. But if you catch anything, I know how to steam it in banana leaves.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Come on, we must know somebody who can do manly stuff like this.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: S’up?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Step one, worms.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Ew!

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, right there, ew is one of the things you’re not gonna want to say in front of your father-in-law. It’s right up there with icky and get it away. Now pick one up.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Really?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: You’re gonna have to do it when you’re fishing.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: What are you waiting for?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I don’t know, for them to die of natural causes.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Just pick up a worm and put him on this hook.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Fine. There.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I’m no expert, but I think the hook has to go through the worm.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Fine. Sorry, Mr. Worm. Sherm. Sherm the Worm.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Hey, don’t name him. Just jab a hook in his face.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: You got this, buddy.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah, come on, Howard. Hook that worm.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: You can do it.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: That’s great. Cheerleading, way to man things up.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (reading)
utterance.content: And the control group displayed significantly fewer genetic abnormalities. But, because of flaws in the experimental design relating to environment and diet, they lived inconclusively ever after. The end.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: That was great. Rub my chest again.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No. I need to get you down for a nap. And for some reason, that VapoRub gets you all fired up.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: How’s the poor thing?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, I’m hanging in there. Thanks for asking.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Okay, Amy, I brought you some drugs we were working on in the lab. This is proving really good for congestion, but there’s a slight chance it can make your tears burn like acid, so if you take it, happy thoughts.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Uh, I’m going to draw you a soothing bath. Where’s your bath thermometer?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I don’t have a bath thermometer.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Fine. Then I’m going to draw you a nerve-wracking bath of indeterminate temperature.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: This is a really good expectorant. Although some test subjects reported lactating uncontrollably when they heard music.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Okay, okay, here’s the deal. I don’t need your medicine. I’m not sick.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: I don’t understand.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I got better two days ago. It’s just been so nice having Sheldon take care of me.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: So you’ve just been lying to him?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: See the stuff in my nose? Rubber cement.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: I don’t mean to be judgy, but this is the kind of thing lunatics do.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: All right. I’ll tell him.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (off)
utterance.content: Amy, would you be strong enough to bathe yourself, or do you need my help?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I’ll tell him tomorrow. Mama needs a bath.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Now, let’s assume, by some miracle, you actually catch a fish. You’re going to have to know how to gut it. So, what you’re going to do is you’re going to take your knife, slice him right up the belly. You want me to stop?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: No, I’m fine. Keep going.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: It’s not our fault. Our dads never did anything like this with us.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: What, never?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: My dad was an anthropologist. The only father-son time he spent was with a 2,000-year-old skeleton of an Etruscan boy. I hated that kid.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Mine just took me to his gynecology office. I got so bored, I’d put vaginal lubricant on the bottom of my shoes and pretend I was ice-skating.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yeah, well, my quality father-son time was spending my adolescence looking out the window waiting for my dad to come back someday.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Yeah, okay, Howard wins.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You know, maybe we didn’t have opportunities like this when we were growing up, but right now, there’s a dad that wants to take you on a fishing trip.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: You’re right. Oh! I should do this.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Great. Here you go. What you’re going to do is you’re going to stick your thumb down its throat, grab the guts and pull.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Here we go. Oh!

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, look, it’s a female. You can see all the eggs.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Oh, Sheldon, am I glad you’re back. Taking a turn for the worst. I think I’m going to need another bath.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m surprised to hear that. See, the other day, I was concerned that you weren’t recovering, so while you were sleeping, I took a cheek swab and had it cultured in the lab.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Oh?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I got the results back. Have you developed any of the following symptoms? A growing nose, or perhaps a warm sensation in the trouser region? Also known as full-blown liar, liar, pants on fire.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: All right, all right. But I really was sick at the beginning. It’s just been so nice having you take care of me.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It hurts that you would lie to me, Amy. I thought our relationship was based on trust and a mutual admiration that skews in my favour.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I feel terrible I did this.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It pains me to say it, but I think some form of penalty is in order, so as to discourage this type of behaviour in the future.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I suppose that’s fair. What do you suggest?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: In a perfect world, I’d lock you in a stockade in the public square. That probably requires a permit.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I could not be allowed to go to the opening of the next Star Trek movie.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, that seems overly harsh. I mean, you gave in to a human weakness, you didn’t kill a man. You know, it’s a tad old-school, but my father was not one to spare the rod when my brother would sneak into his truck and drink his driving whiskey.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Are you saying you want to spank me?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I don’t want to. But it looks like you left me no choice.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: That’s true. I’ve been a very bad girl.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Hi-ho, hi-ho, it’s off to fish we go.

utterance.speaker: Mr. Rostenkowski
utterance.content: That’s what you’re wearing?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: No good? The guy at the sporting goods store said these are what fishermen wear.

utterance.speaker: Mr. Rostenkowski
utterance.content: Maybe in cartoons.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Wish I had known that before I posted all those pictures on Facebook.

utterance.speaker: Mr. Rostenkowski
utterance.content: All right, let’s hit the road. I wouldn’t mind shooting some ducks in the morning.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Wait, now we’re shooting things?

utterance.speaker: Mr. Rostenkowski
utterance.content: I like using a big shell. You can’t eat them afterwards, but it’s fun watching them blow up.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Sir, I’m flattered that you invited me, and I really want you to like me, but I don’t think this trip is the way to do it. And I can’t return these things if there’s chunks of duck all over them.

utterance.speaker: Mr. Rostenkowski
utterance.content: So, why’d you agree to come?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: ‘Cause Bernadette made me.

utterance.speaker: Mr. Rostenkowski
utterance.content: I tried to back out, too. My wife said I had to go.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Really? Your wife makes you do stuff? You’re a big, scary cop.

utterance.speaker: Mr. Rostenkowski
utterance.content: You’re an astronaut, and your wife makes you do things, and she’s only four feet tall.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: So, what do we do now? They expect us to go away for the weekend.

utterance.speaker: Mr. Rostenkowski
utterance.content: Ah. There’s an Indian casino near Palm Springs. You know how to shoot craps?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: No, but I’m not a stranger to dice games. I was the Temple Beth-El Hebrew School Yahtzee champion.

utterance.speaker: Mr. Rostenkowski
utterance.content: Mazel tov. I’ll teach you how to play.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Really? Thank you, sir.

utterance.speaker: Mr. Rostenkowski
utterance.content: Call me Mike.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Okay. Oh, boy, we’re just married to a couple of ballbusters, huh, Mike?

utterance.speaker: Mr. Rostenkowski
utterance.content: That’s my wife and daughter you’re talking about.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Great couple of gals.

utterance.speaker: Mr. Rostenkowski
utterance.content: I wouldn’t go that far.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Are you prepared to receive your punishment?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: One second. I want to put on some music.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: I don’t want to disturb the people next door while you discipline me.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Very well, then. Get over my knee. Let’s begin.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Oh, my.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Excuse me. You’re not supposed to be enjoying this.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Then maybe you should spank me harder.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Maybe I will.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Ooh!
